definitions.definition: if you wish somebody a Happy Birthday, Happy New Year, etc. you mean that you hope they have a pleasant celebration
satisfied that something is good or right; not anxious
definitions.sensetop: happy with somebody/somethinghappy about somebody/somethinghappy about somebody/something doing something

examples.text: I don't know what you've done, but the boss isn't happy.
I said I'd go just to **keep him happy**.
Are you happy with that arrangement?
I'm not happy with his work this term.
She was **happy enough** with her performance.
If there's anything you're not happy about, come and ask.
I'm **not too happy** about her living alone.
Dad seemed perfectly happy with my explanation.
I was quite happy with the way things went.
He went home from time to time, to keep his mother happy.

definitions.definition: willing or pleased to do something

examples.text: I'm **perfectly happy** to leave it till tomorrow.
People seemed **quite happy** to help.
He will be **more than happy** to come with us.
We'd be **only too happy** to accept your invitation.
By **a happy coincidence**, we arrived at exactly the same time.
He is in the happy position of never having to worry about money.

I picked the restaurant pretty much at random, but it proved a happy choice all round.

definitions.definition: suitable and appropriate for a particular situation

examples.text: That wasn't the happiest choice of words.
She wasn't a happy bunny at all.

definitions.definition: a course of action that is not extreme
something that is in the middle between two choices or two ways of doing something

examples.text: She tried to strike a happy medium between making the questions too hard and making them too easy.

definitions.definition: used to wish somebody a happy and pleasant birthday

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘lucky’): from the noun hap ‘good fortune’ + -y.
